title: 103_hr3464
content: The Act is titled the "Comprehensive Arson Deterrence and Fire Containment Act of 1993." It authorizes $15,000,000 for the modernization or replacement of the Modular Airborne Fire Fighting System used by the United States Forest Service to improve fire fighting response time. The Forest Service, in consultation with fire chiefs and experts, will study ways to improve airborne fire fighting response time and report to Congress within a year. Additionally, the Act proposes increased criminal penalties for arsonists. The Act proposes increased criminal penalties for arsonists, amending federal property laws to fine or imprison offenders for up to 10 years. The Act proposes increased criminal penalties for arsonists, with fines or imprisonment up to 10 years. Offenders causing over $1,000,000 in damage face fines and 5 to 20 years in prison. If a person's life is endangered, the punishment is also severe. If the damage caused by the offense exceeds $1,000,000, the offender faces a fine and 5 to 20 years in prison. If a person's life is endangered or the damage exceeds $10,000,000, the punishment is more severe. If the damage caused by the offense exceeds $10,000,000 or personal injury results in damage exceeding $25,000,000, the offender faces a fine and imprisonment for 8 to 30 years or 10 to 40 years, respectively. If the offense results in the death of any person, the offender faces a fine and imprisonment. If the damage caused by the offense exceeds $25,000,000 or if the offense results in the death of any person, the offender shall face a fine, imprisonment for not less than 10 nor more than 40 years, and potentially the death penalty. The offender may face imprisonment for more than 25 years or life, and potentially the death penalty, for certain offenses. Interstate commerce laws are also amended to increase penalties. Title 18, United States Code is amended to impose fines or imprisonment up to 10 years for offenses, with increased penalties for damages exceeding $1,000,000. If the damage caused by the offense exceeds $1,000,000, the offender shall be subject to a fine and imprisoned for 5 to 20 years. If the life of any person is placed in jeopardy or the damage exceeds $10,000,000, the offender shall be fined and imprisoned for 8 to 30 years. If personal injury results or damage exceeds $25,000,000, the offender faces a fine and imprisonment for 10 to 40 years. In case of death, the offender will face consequences. If personal injury results or damage exceeds $25,000,000, the offender faces a fine and imprisonment for 10 to 40 years. In case of death, the offender may also face the death penalty. If personal injury results or damage exceeds $25,000,000, the offender faces a fine and imprisonment for 10 to 40 years. In case of death, the offender may also face the death penalty. Additionally, if the death of any person results, the offender shall be subject to a fine, imprisonment for more than 25 years (or life), and the death penalty as provided in section 34 of this title. Section 844 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include penalties for reckless use of fire or explosives resulting in injury or property damage to a dwelling. Offenders may face fines, imprisonment up to one year, or both. If no imprisonment is imposed, probation with conditions is mandatory. If a person (other than the offender) is injured or property is damaged, the offender may be fined or imprisoned for up to one year. If not imprisoned, probation with community service is required. Juveniles may be sent to a residential institution for at least one week for similar offenses. In juvenile proceedings, a delinquent must spend a week in a residential institution and do 400-2000 hours of community service. Negligent conduct violating certain subsections may result in a fine, imprisonment up to one month, or both. In juvenile proceedings, a delinquent must spend time in a residential institution and perform community service hours. Negligent conduct may lead to fines, imprisonment, or probation with community service hours. A person convicted under this section may be sentenced to probation with a condition of 100-1000 hours of community service. In juvenile proceedings, a delinquent must spend time in a residential institution and perform community service hours. The Forest Service will study federal legal barriers to clearing fire hazards with input from fire experts and report findings to Congress within a year. Defense conversion will be used to enhance private firefighting capabilities. The Secretary of Defense, in consultation with the Federal Aviation Administration, will report to Congress on utilizing excess military cargo and private fire fighting contractors for fire fighting purposes. Additionally, a report will be made on reforming Federal aviation regulations to maximize the use of planes for fire fighting. The Forest Service, in consultation with fire chiefs and experts, will study building roads and backup power for water supply in national forests to enhance fire fighting. Results will be reported to Congress within a year. SEC. 8. REVENUE OFFSET. The Secretary of Agriculture will reduce below-cost direct loans of the Farmers Home Administration by 5% for fiscal years 1994 through 1998.
